summary: The case concerns an application by Vincenzo Ettore Buscemi, an Italian national, against the Italian Republic, alleging violations of Articles 8 and 6(1) of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The applicant's daughter was taken into custody by the Italian authorities, and the applicant was denied access to her. The applicant alleged that the President of the Turin Youth Court was biased against him and made statements to the press that damaged his reputation and family life. The applicant claimed that the custody award was unfair and that he was not given a fair opportunity to present his case. The Court found that the measures taken by the court were in accordance with the law and pursued a legitimate aim of protecting the rights of others, but the manner in which the expert report was prepared did not breach Article 8. The Court also found that the President's statements to the press implied that he had already formed an unfavorable view of the applicant's case, which was incompatible with the impartiality required by Article 6(1) of the Convention. The Court awarded the applicant just satisfaction, including reimbursement of expenses incurred before the Convention institutions.
